entry.title: A simple neural network to predict galaxy rotation curves from photometry

link.title: A simple neural network to predict galaxy rotation curves from photometry

entry.summary: Designing a simple feedforward neural network, made with just linear layers, activations, and batch normalization, to predict rotation curves from galaxy surface brightness profiles. Comparison to the MOND empirical law.

entry.title: Rotation curve decompositions with Gaussian Processes: taking into account data correlations leads to unbiased results

link.title: Rotation curve decompositions with Gaussian Processes: taking into account data correlations leads to unbiased results

entry.summary: Correlations between velocity measurements in disk galaxy rotation curves are usually neglected when fitting dynamical models. This notebook, which accompanies the paper Posti (2022), Res. Notes AAS, 6, 233, shows how data correlations can be taken into account in rotation curve decompositions using Gaussian Processes.

entry.title: Gaussian Processes: modelling correlated noise in a dataset

link.title: Gaussian Processes: modelling correlated noise in a dataset

entry.summary: Independent datapoints are most often just a convenient idealisation which can even hamper your model inference at times and bias your results. Learn how to embrace the reality of correlated noise in the data and marginalize the parameter posteriors with Gaussian Processes.

entry.title: Variational Autoencoder: learning an underlying distribution and generating new data

link.title: Variational Autoencoder: learning an underlying distribution and generating new data

entry.summary: Constructing an autoencoder that learns the underlying distribution of the input data, generated from a multi-dimensional smooth function `f=f(x_1,x_2,x_3,x_4)`. This can be used to generate new data, sampling from the learned distribution

entry.title: Autoencoder represents a multi-dimensional smooth function

link.title: Autoencoder represents a multi-dimensional smooth function

entry.summary: Setting up a simple `Autoencoder` neural network to reproduce a dataset obtained by sampling a multi-dimensional smooth function `f=f(x_1,x_2,x_3,x_4)`. As an example I'm using a disc+halo rotation curve model where both components are described by 2-parameters circular velocities
